lesson.name: Lesson 5.13: Reasoning about Exponential Graphs, Part 2

page.title: 5.13.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will investigate the relationship between the parameters \(a\) and \(b\) in the expression \(a \cdot b^x\) and a graph representing the function \(f\) given by \(f(x)=a \cdot b^x\). You will start by identifying a function represented by a given graph and using the graph to make sense of a situation. You will also examine two abstract graphs, with unlabeled axes, and decide which one represents a given situation. In both cases, you will use your understanding of the connections between the parameters in an exponential expression and the features of an exponential graph to answer questions.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to: 

  • Explain the meaning of the intersection of the graphs of two functions in terms of the situations they represent.
  • Write an equation for the function given two points on a graph of an exponential function.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 5.13.1: Comparing Functions
  • 5.13.2: Creating Exponential Functions from Graphs
    • 5.13.2: Self Check 
  • 5.13.3: Comparing Exponential Functions
    • 5.13.3: Self Check 
  • 5.13.4: Interpreting Features of an Exponential Graph

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 5.13.5: Practice
  • 5.13.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 5.13.1: Comparing Functions
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Which one doesn’t belong?

\(f(n)=8 \cdot 2^n\)

\(g(n)=2 \cdot 8^n\)

\(h(n)=8+2n\)

\(j(n)=8 \cdot (\frac{1}{2})^n\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(f\) is the only one that doubles when \(n\) increases by 1.

\(g\) is the only one that does not have 8 for its vertical intercept.

\(h\) is the only one that is not an exponential function.

\(j\) is the only one that is not increasing.

page.title: 5.13.2: Creating Exponential Functions from Graphs
page.contents:
Activity

  1. Here is a graph representing an exponential function \(f\). The function \(f\) gives the value of a computer, in dollars, as a function of time, \(x\), measured in years since the time of purchase.

Based on the graph, what can you say about the following?


  1. The purchase price of the computer

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

$400


  1. The value of \(f\) when \(x\) is 1

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(f(1)=200\)


  1. The meaning of \(f(1)\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

The value of the computer after 1 year


  1. How the value of the computer is changing each year

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

The computer loses half of its value each year.


  1. An equation that defines \(f\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(f(x)=400(\frac{1}{2})^x\) or equivalent (i.e., \(f(x)=400 \cdot (0.5)^x\)).


  1. Whether the value of \(f\) will reach 0 after 10 years

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

No, it will not. After 10 years, the value of the computer will be a little less than $0.40.


Video: Interpreting an Exponential Function from a Graph

Watch the following video to learn more about interpreting exponential functions:


  1. Here are graphs of two exponential functions. For each, write an equation that defines the function and find the value of the function when \(x\) is 5.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(f(x)=5\cdot 3^x\) and \(f(5)=1,215\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(f(x)=20 \cdot (\frac{1}{2})^x\) (or equivalent, i.e., \(f(x)=20 \cdot (0.5)^x\)) and \(f(5)=0.625\) (or equivalent).


Extending Your Thinking

Consider a function \(f\) defined by \(f(x)=a \cdot b^x\).

If the graph of \(f\) goes through the points \((2,10)\) and \((8,30)\), would you expect \(f(5)\) to be less than, equal to, or greater than 20?

If the graph of \(f\) goes through the points \((2,30)\) and \((8,10)\), would you expect \(f(5)\) to be less than, equal to, or greater than 20?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The value 20 is what you would get for \(f(5)\) if \(f\) were a linear function through \((2,10)\) and \((8,30)\) (or \((2,30)\) and \((8,10)\)). Looking at graphs representing our exponential functions, we can see that the line connecting two points on the graph always seems to be above the graph of the exponential function itself. Thus, we would expect \(f(5)<20\) in both cases.

page.title: 5.13.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following is the function for the curve graphed below?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The starting value must be multiplied by the growth factor. The answer is \(f(x)=100 \cdot 3^x\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(a\) and \(b\) need to be switched. The answer is \(f(x)=100 \cdot 3^x\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The starting value was 100, and the growth factor is 3.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Only the 3 should be raised to the \(x\) power. The answer is \(f(x)=100 \cdot 3^x\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.13.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Writing Functions from Graphs

Find the equation of the function graphed above. Then find the value at \(f(5)\).

  1. Find the value of \(a\), the starting point.

\(a=4\)
  1. Find the \(b\), the growth factor.

\(b=3\)
  1. Write the equation of the function.

\(f(x)=4 \cdot 3^x\)
  1. Find \(f(5)\).

\(f(5)=4 \cdot 3^5=972\)

Try It: Writing Functions from Graphs

Use the graph below to write the equation of the function. Then find \(f(5)\).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Here is how to write the exponential function from the graph:

  1. Find the value of \(a\), the starting point.

\(a=2\)
  1. Find the \(b\), the growth factor.

\(b=4\)
  1. Write the equation of the function.

\(f(x)=2 \cdot 4^x\)
  1. Find \(f(5)\).

\(f(x)=2 \cdot 4^5=2048\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.13.3: Comparing Exponential Functions
page.contents:
Activity

Here are graphs representing two functions and descriptions of two functions.

  • Function \(f\): The area of a wall that is covered by Mold A, in square inches, doubling every month.
  • Function \(g\): The area of a wall that is covered by Mold B, in square inches, tripling every month.
  1. Which graph represents each function? Explain your answer.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Since Mold B is growing more quickly, the graph that shows a greater growth factor (the one starting lower and ending higher) is function \(g\) (solid).



  1. When the mold was first spotted and measured, was there more of Mold A or Mold B? Explain how you know.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

There was more of Mold A. The graph for \(f\) (dashed) shows a greater vertical intercept.




  1. What does the point \((p,q)\) tell us in this situation? Explain your answer.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

After \(p\) months, there was the same amount of Mold A and Mold B on the wall (\(q\) square inches), after which Mold B started to have larger area than Mold A.

page.title: 5.13.3: Self Check
page.contents: In the formula \(f(x)=a \cdot b^x\), what changes on the graph when \(a\) changes?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(a\) value changes the vertical intercept. The answer is the \(y\)-intercept.
That’s correct! Check yourself: The \(a\) value in the exponential function causes the value when \(x = 0\) to change.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The slope is affected by changes in \(b\). The answer is the \(y\)-intercept.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The growth factor is affected by changes in \(b\). The answer is the \(y\)-intercept.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 5.13.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Reading Exponential Graphs

The graphs of \(f\) and \(g\) are located below and are functions of the form \(y=a \cdot b^x\).

Which curve has the larger \(a\) value? 

\(f(x)\) because its \(y\)-intercept is higher.

Which curve has the larger \(b\) value?

\(g(x)\) because it is growing more quickly.

Try It: Reading Exponential Graphs

The graphs of \(f\) and \(g\) are located below and are functions of the form \(y=ab^x\).

Which curve has the larger \(b\) value?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(f(x)\) has the larger \(b\) value because it is growing faster than \(g(x)\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.13.4: Interpreting Features of an Exponential Graph
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Here are two graphs representing the function \(f\) given by \(f(x)=10 \cdot 2^x\) and the function \(g\) defined by \(g(x)=a \cdot b^x\).

  1. Is \(b\) greater than or less than 2? Explain how you know.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(b\) is greater than 2.

  • The graph of \(g\) starts off being below the graph of \(f\), but later it surpasses the graph of \(f\). Since \(g\) grows more quickly than \(f\), the growth factor \(b\) for \(g\) must be greater than the growth factor for \(f\), which is 2.
  • The growth factor from the first point \((0,3)\) to the second point \((1,12)\) is 4 because \(\frac{12}{3}=4\), and 4 is greater than 2.


  1. Write an equation that defines \(g\). Explain your answer.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(g(x)=3 \cdot 4^x\) because the initial value is 3 and the \(y\)-value is multiplied by 4 when the \(x\)-value increases by 1, so the growth factor is 4.



  1. \(f\) and \(g\) represent the number, in thousands, of social media followers of two organizations as a function of years since 2010. What does the intersection of \(f\) and \(g\) mean in this context? 

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

It represents the time, in years since 2010, when the two organizations have the same number of followers.

page.title: 5.13.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Here is a graph of \(p\), an insect population, \(w\) weeks after it was first measured. The population grows exponentially. 
    1. What is the weekly factor of growth for the insect population? Enter integers only.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.13.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What was the population when it was first measured? Enter integers only.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.13.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 300. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Write an equation relating \(p\) and \(w\).

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.13.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(p=300 \cdot 3^w\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Here is a graph of the function \(f\) defined by \(f(x)=a \cdot b^x\).

    Select all possible values of \(b\).

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.13.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(\frac{1}{10}\), \(\frac12\), and \(\frac{9}{10}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The function \(f\) is given by \(f(x)=50\cdot (\frac{1}{2})^x\), and the function \(g\) is given by \(g(x)=50 \cdot (\frac{1}{3})^x\).
    Here are graphs of \(f\) and \(g\).



    Which graph is the graph of \(f(x)\)?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 5.13.3–5.13.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Graph 1. The growth factor for \(f(x)\) is greater than that of \(g(x)\), so \(f(x)\) lies above \(g(x)\) on the graph. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The function \(f\) is defined by \(f(x)=50 \cdot 3^x\). The function \(g\) is defined by \(g(x)=a \cdot b^x\).
    Here are graphs of \(f\) and \(g\).



    1. In \(g(x)\), \(a\) is greater than/less than 50.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.13.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is greater than. The \(y\)-intercept of \(g\) is above the \(y\)-intercept of \(f\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. In \(g(x)\), \(b\) is greater than/less than 3.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.13.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is less than. In \(g(x)\), \(b\) is less than 3 (but still larger than 1) because the growth rate of \(f\) is faster than the growth rate of \(g\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 5.13.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain the meaning of the intersection of the graphs of two functions in terms of the situations they represent.
  • Write an equation for the function given two points on a graph of an exponential function.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 5.13.1: Comparing Functions
    • In this activity, you looked closely at functions and explained the ways in which they were similar or distinct.
  • 5.13.2: Creating Exponential Functions from Graphs 
    • In this activity, you analyzed graphs of exponential functions to identify the initial value and the growth factor. You then created corresponding equations for the functions.
  • 5.13.2: Self Check 
  • 5.13.3: Comparing Exponential Functions
    • In this activity, you were presented with two graphs without numerical values assigned to any points on the graphs. Using the graphs, you compared their starting values and growth factors in the context of the situation. You also analyzed the point of intersection.
  • 5.13.3: Self Check 
  • 5.13.4: Interpreting Features of an Exponential Graph
    • In this activity, you used the graph of a given exponential function to determine possible values in the equation of the other exponential function.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 5.13.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
